title: Nouns
definition: a word used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things
explanation: Nouns can be either singular or plural, and can be used as the subject or object of a sentence.

title: Pronouns
definition: a word used in place of a noun to avoid repetition
explanation: Pronouns can be personal (e.g. he, she, they), possessive (e.g. his, hers, theirs), demonstrative (e.g. this, that), or relative (e.g. who, whom, whose).

title: Verbs
definition: a word used to describe an action, state, or occurrence
explanation: Verbs can be either regular or irregular, and can be used in different tenses to indicate when the action occurred.

title: Adjectives
definition: a word used to describe or modify a noun or pronoun
explanation: Adjectives can be used to indicate the size, color, shape, or other qualities of a noun or pronoun.

title: Adverbs
definition: a word used to describe or modify a verb, adjective, or other adverb
explanation: Adverbs can be used to indicate the time, place, manner, or degree of an action or quality.

title: Prepositions
definition: a word used to show the relationship between a noun or pronoun and other words in a sentence
explanation: Prepositions can be used to indicate location, time, or other relationships between words.

title: Conjunctions
definition: a word used to join words, phrases, or clauses together
explanation: Conjunctions can be used to indicate the relationship between words or clauses, such as addition, contrast, or cause and effect.

title: Interjections
definition: a word used to express strong emotion or surprise
explanation: Interjections are often used at the beginning of a sentence, and are not grammatically related to the rest of the sentence.

title: Subject
definition: the person, place, thing, or idea that the sentence is about
explanation: The subject can be a noun, pronoun, or other noun phrase.

title: Predicate
definition: the part of a sentence that contains the verb and describes the action or state of the subject
explanation: The predicate can be a verb, verb phrase, or other phrase that describes the subject.

title: Object
definition: the person, place, thing, or idea that is affected by the action of the verb
explanation: The object can be a noun, pronoun, or other noun phrase.

title: Phrase
definition: a group of words that functions as a unit within a sentence
explanation: Phrases can be noun phrases, verb phrases, or other types of phrases.

title: Clause
definition: a group of words that contains a subject and a predicate
explanation: Clauses can be independent (complete sentences) or dependent (incomplete sentences that rely on another clause).

title: Infinitive
definition: the base form of a verb, usually preceded by 'to'
explanation: Infinitives can be used as noun phrases, adjective phrases, or adverb phrases.

title: Gerund
definition: a verb form that ends in -ing and functions as a noun
explanation: Gerunds can be used as subjects, objects, or complements in a sentence.

title: Participle
definition: a verb form that can be used as an adjective
explanation: Participles can be present (-ing) or past (-ed), and describe the subject of the sentence.

title: Tenses
definition: the form of a verb that indicates when the action occurred
explanation: Tenses can be present, past, or future, and can be simple, continuous, perfect, or perfect continuous.
examples: future perfect: They will have arrived

title: Declarative Sentences
definition: a sentence that makes a statement or assertion
explanation: Declarative sentences end with a period, and can be positive or negative.

title: Interrogative Sentences
definition: a sentence that asks a question
explanation: Interrogative sentences end with a question mark, and can be yes/no questions or wh- questions.

title: Imperative Sentences
definition: a sentence that gives a command or instruction
explanation: Imperative sentences can be positive or negative, and often do not include a subject.

title: Exclamatory Sentences
definition: a sentence that expresses strong emotion or surprise
explanation: Exclamatory sentences end with an exclamation mark, and often begin with 'what' or 'how'.

title: Subject-Verb Agreement
definition: the agreement between the subject and verb in a sentence
explanation: The verb must agree with the subject in number (singular or plural) and person (first, second, or third).

title: Pronoun-Antecedent Agreement
definition: the agreement between a pronoun and its antecedent (the noun it replaces)
explanation: The pronoun must agree with the antecedent in number (singular or plural) and gender (masculine, feminine, or neuter).
examples: They are going to their house.

title: Definite Article ('the')
definition: the article used to refer to a specific noun
explanation: The definite article is used before a noun that has already been mentioned or is known to both the speaker and listener.

title: Indefinite Articles ('a,' 'an')
definition: the articles used to refer to any member of a class of nouns
explanation: The indefinite article 'a' is used before a noun that begins with a consonant sound, and the indefinite article 'an' is used before a noun that begins with a vowel sound.
